notesStmt.note:
This notebook contains several dated entries, all of which suggest that it was inscribed during the fall of 1856. On the recto of leaf 3 is a quotation taken from the New York Express, dated "Oct. 21, 1856"; on the verso of leaf 44 is the inscription "A. Brownson [sic] Alcott Oct. 4th '56"; and the inside back cover shows the date 16th Sept. Fredson Bowers has speculated, based on the locations of the dated entries, that all of the material that contributed to Whitman's poetry was written sometime after 21 October 1856. (See Bowers, Whitman's Manuscripts: Leaves of Grass [1860] A Parallel Text [Chicago: The University of Chicago Press, 1955], xxxiii–li, 40–56.) It is of course possible, however, that parts of the notebook were inscribed before and/or after the dated entries. Much of the notebook is devoted to draft material for the 1860 poem eventually titled "Starting from Paumanok," and one brief passage (on the verso of leaf 25) seems clearly to have contributed to "Song at Sunset," another 1860 poem. Two passages suggest possible (though less certain) connections to poems that appeared in earlier editions of Leaves of Grass. On the verso of the sixteenth leaf is a passage with similarities to the 1856 poem eventually titled "Miracles," and on the recto of the fifth leaf are lines that might have contributed to the first poem of the 1855 Leaves of Grass, ultimately titled "Song of Myself."
This is one of several notebooks that Whitman filled from both ends. That is, rather than choosing one cover as the "front" and writing all the way through to the "back," Whitman treated both covers as "fronts," with the result that about half of the pages are inscribed upside-down relative to the other pages. It is unclear which pages were inscribed first; furthermore, several of the leaves have become detached and seem to have been moved to different positions over the years by those examining the notebook. For this reason, we have chosen to base our ordering of the pages on Fredson Bowers's transcription, since it offers the earliest account of the notebook's state. It should be noted that this ordering differs significantly from the current disposition of the notebook and that both of these also differ from the ordering in the transcription of William White, Daybooks and Notebooks (New York: New York University Press, 1978), 3:777–803. Note also that some of the page images have been rotated to make them easily readable.

div1.head: N.Y. Express, Oct. 21, 1856
div1.p: "But for the American party, the Northern, sectional, geographical party of Wm H. Seward & Co. would, under Fremont, have swept the whole Northern country." (editorial.)

lg.head: Proem.—
Proem of all
lg.l:
These are the candid
open-shown thoughts
of me, and of all
my body & soul

Lo, the amp free open amplitude
over and over
Lo the round globe, tumbling

Lo, friendly persons advancing,
tall, muscular, friendly with
sufficient hands and feet,

Lo—the great women of upon of the world
the New World—and the lo
how they precede the beard-faced masters
of upon the world,

note.p: This passage is possibly related to the following line of the first poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, later titled "Song of Myself": "It is for the illiterate . . . . it is for the judges of the supreme court . . . . it is for the federal capitol and the state capitols."

lg.l: Lo

Shall speak in the Presidents
Message from the porch
of the Federal Capitol, and in
the Governors' Messages
from the State Capitols,
and in the rulings of
the Judges of the
Supreme Court,

div1.head: Commencement of Discourse
"Spiritualism"
div1.p: Life is very great but theere f is something greater than life, absorbing life, namely Death.—When as we are in the midst of affairs, going to dinner, &c, we receive the news of the sudden death of — —over

note.p: Several words and phrases in the following lines suggest that they constitute an early draft of a passage in "Proto-Leaf," the first poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass, later retitled "Starting from Paumanok." The published lines begin "Whoever you are! to you endless announcements" and include addresses "Toward the male of The States, and toward the female of The States" as well as "Toward the President, the Congress . . . ." Several other versions of this passage are scattered throughout this notebook.

lg.head: Proem
Preface of Endless Announcements
lg.l:
Toward the perfect woman
of The America

Toward the perfect man
of America

Toward the President
of These States, and
the members of
the Congress of These
States

note.p: This brief note apparently shows Whitman experimenting with the opening phrase and/or title of the passage above. Like that and many other entries in this notebook, this note constitutes draft material toward "Proto-Leaf," the introductory poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass (in later editions retitled "Starting from Paumanok"), which contains the line "Whoever you are! to you endless announcements."

div1.p: After all is said, it remains to be said, This too is great in its reference to death

lg.head: Poem of Remorse
lg.l:
I now look back to the
times when I thought
others—slaves?—the ignorant?
—so much inferior to my self

To have so much less right
than myself

O you round Earth,
I

note.p: These lines contributed to the opening lines of "Proto-Leaf," the first poem in the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass, later titled "Starting from Paumanok."

note.p: The following passage is one of several drafts in this notebook of the following line from "Proto-Leaf," the introductory poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass: "Whoever you are! to you endless announcements." The poem was later retitled "Starting from Paumanok."

real love personal

note.p: The phrases "To you, endless announcements!" and "Whoever you are" were used, with slight modifications, in a late passage of "Proto-Leaf," the first poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass. The poem was later retitled "Starting from Paumanok."
The later lines in this passage contributed to the opening lines of the same poem.

note.p: These lines probably contributed to "Proto-Leaf," the introductory poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass. The published lines read, "Inextricable lands! the clutched together! the passionate lovers! / The side by side! the elder and younger brothers! the bony-limbed! / The great women's land! the feminine! the experienced sisters and the inexperienced sisters!"

note.p: These lines contributed to the following passage of "Proto-Leaf," the introductory poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass: "Far breath'd land! Arctic braced! Mexican breezed! the diverse! the compact! [. . . ] O I cannot be discharged from you! / O Death! O for all that, I am yet of you, unseen, this hour, with irrepressible love." The poem was later retitled "Starting from Paumanok."

note.p: The first two groups of lines on this page contributed to the following passage of "Proto-Leaf," the first poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass: "This then is life, / Here is what has come to the surface after so many / throes and convulsions. / How curious! How real! / Underfoot the divine soil—Overhead the sun." The poem was later retitled "Starting from Paumanok."
The third group of lines seems to have contributed to a slightly later passage of the same poem: "Take my leaves, America! / Make welcome for them everywhere, for they are your own offspring"

note.p: It is possible that the lines on this page contributed to a passage of the poem "Proto-Leaf," which was published in the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass and later retitled "Starting from Paumanok." Among the parallels between the two are references to "the Louisianian," "the Georgian," "the Mississippian," and "[the] Arkansian."

note.p: The first passage on this page is perhaps related to "Poem of Perfect Miracles," published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass. After much revision, the poem was eventually retitled "Miracles," though by that time the relevant line ("Or the admirable sight of the perfect old man, or the perfect old woman") had been deleted.

The second passage on this page probably represents an early draft of the following line of "Proto-Leaf," the first poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass: "And sexual organs and acts! do you concentrate in me—For I am determined to tell you with courageous clear voice, to prove you illustrious." The poem was later retitled "Starting from Paumanok."

note.p: These lines contributed to the third line of "Proto-Leaf," which was first published in the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass and later titled "Starting from Paumanok." The published line reads, "Fond of fish-shape Paumanok, where I was born."

note.p: This draft appears to consist of several versions of lines that Whitman used in the poem "Proto-Leaf," first published in the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass: "How curious! How real! / Underfoot the divine soil—Overhead the sun." The poem was eventually retitled "Starting from Paumanok."

note.p: The first line of this draft, "How curious . . . real earth!" represents an early version of the lines "How curious! How real! / Underfoot the divine soil—Overhead the sun," which appeared in "Proto-Leaf," the first poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass.

note.p: The first two lines of this draft ("Forever and Thy soul! . . . water ebbs and flows") contributed to the following lines of "Proto-Leaf," the poem that introduced the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass: "The SOUL! / Forever and forever—Longer than soil is brown and solid—Longer than water ebbs and flows." The poem was later retitled "Starting from Paumanok."
The line "Life,—how curious! how real" contributed to another line that occurs earlier in the same poem: "How curious! How real!"
The final two lines of this draft, "Underfoot, the divine soil, / Overhead, the sun," were also used in "Proto-Leaf," placed immediately after "How curious! How real!"

The lines "Space and time . . . animals, identity, eyesight" probably led to a passage in the eighth "Chants Democratic" poem of the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was eventually titled "Song at Sunset." The passage begins, "Illustrious every one!" and concludes, "To breathe the air, how delicious!"

lg.head: Forever and Thy soul!
lg.l:

as the than soilground is brown and solid, as longer
as than water ebbs and
flows

you O my soul shall never
give place!
Life,—how curious! how real

Space, and time, filled with such
easy wonders!
To walk, to breathe, how delicious

The daylig day; these the
curious; divine,
animals, identity,
eyesight!

Underfoot, the divine
soil,
Overhead, the sun.

note.p: There is a distant possibility that this passage relates to the following line in the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself": "Eleves I salute you" (1855, p. 44).

note.p: The first four lines of this passage, "This then is life . . . overhead the sun," were incorporated, in edited form, into an early section of the 1860–1861 poem "Proto-Leaf," which was eventually titled "Starting from Paumanok."
The next two lines, "Surround my poems . . . for they are for you," were used in a later section of the same poem.

note.p: The lines on this page bear a faint resemblance to a passage in the poem "Proto-Leaf," published in the 1860–1861 edition of Leaves of Grass, which reads, in part, "And I will show of male and female that either is but the equal of the other, / And I will show that there is no imperfection in male or female, or in the earth [. . .] ." The poem was later retitled "Starting from Paumanok."

lg.head: In Poem
lg.l:
The earth, that is my model of poems
model—I do not ? none need
discard what I
find in the theory
of the great, round diversified
earth, so beautiful, and
so rude.

The body of a man,— that
I is my model—I do
not reject what I
find in my body—I
am not ashamed—Why
should I be ashamed?

The body of a woman,—
that is my perfect
model—I believe
in all the body of
the woman—I believe
the perfect woman
shall even precede
the man

lg.head: Poem of Maternity
lg.l:
O my dear child! My
Darling

(Now I am maternal—
a child bearer—
I bea have from

For great ideas!

long list of cities

Have you any doubt of mortality?

I say there can be no more

there is of mortality

div1.p: American songs,—in which prose (to be spoken—with a low, or other musical accompaniment,) is interlineated
I had rather have the good will of the butchers and boatmen of Manhattan Island than all the nominations approbation rewards of the government—literats elegant persons
Walt Whitman stands to-day in the midst of the American people, a promise, a preface, an overture a

Will he fulfil the half-distinct half-indistinct promise?—Many do not understand him, but there are others, a few, who do understand him. Will he justify the great prophecy of Emerson? or will he too, like thousands of others, flaunt out the one bright commencement, the result of gathered powers, only to sink back exhausted—or to give himself up to the seduction of

with notes on Russia, Koords,
